required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Brivaracetam as add-on Treatment in Adolescents and Adults Suffering From Epilepsy
clinical_study.official_title: An International, Randomized, Double-blind, Parallel-group, Placebo-controlled, Flexible Dose Study: Evaluation of the Safety and Efficacy of Brivaracetam in Subjects (≥ 16 to 70 Years Old) Suffering From Localization-related or Generalized Epilepsy.

brief_summary.textblock: This study will compare the safety and efficacy of Brivaracetam at flexible dose with Placebo in subjects suffering from Epilepsy.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Subjects With at Least One Adverse Event During the 16-week Treatment Period
primary_outcome.time_frame: Week 2 to the end of the Treatment Period (Week 16)
primary_outcome.description: An Adverse Event (AE) is any untoward medical occurrence in a patient or clinical investigation subject administered a pharmaceutical product which does not necessarily have a causal relationship with this treatment. An AE can therefore be any unfavorable and unintended sign (including an abnormal laboratory finding), symptom, or disease temporally associated with the use of a medicinal (investigational) product, whether or not related to the medicinal (investigational) product.

primary_outcome.measure: Partial Onset Seizure (Type I) Frequency Per Week Over the 16-week Treatment Period
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (Week 0) to the end of the Treatment Period (Week 16)
primary_outcome.description: Partial (Type I) seizures can be classified into one of the following three groups: Simple partial seizures Complex partial seizures Partial seizures evolving to generalized tonic-clonic convulsions. Partial Onset Seizure (POS) frequency per week over the Treatment Period (TP) was calculated as: (Total Type I seizures over the TP)*7/(Total number of days with no missing seizure count in the TP)

secondary_outcome.measure: Responder Rate for Partial Onset Seizures (Type I) Frequency Per Week Over the 16-week Treatment Period
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (Week 0) to the end of Treatment Period (Week 16)
secondary_outcome.description: The responder rate was presented as the percentage of responders and non-responders. A subject is a responder, if the subject has at least 50 % reduction in Partial Onset Seizure frequency per week from Baseline to Treatment Period. Subjects with zero seizure frequency per week at Baseline were considered as non-responders.

secondary_outcome.measure: Seizure Frequency (All Seizure Types) Per Week Over the 16-week Treatment Period
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (Week 0) to the end of Treatment Period (Week 16)
secondary_outcome.description: There are three different types of seizures: Type I: Partial seizures Type II: Generalized seizures Type III: Unclassified epileptic seizures. All seizure frequency per week over Treatment Period (TP) was calculated as: (Total number of seizures over the TP)*7/(Total number of days with no missing seizure count in the TP)

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline to the 16-week Treatment Period in Partial Onset Seizure (Type I) Frequency Per Week
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (Week 0) to end of Treatment Period (Week 16)
secondary_outcome.description: Percent change from Baseline was calculated as percent reduction by: (weekly seizure frequency Baseline - weekly seizure frequency Treatment)*100/(weekly seizure frequency Baseline). A negative value in percent Change from Baseline indicates an improvement from Baseline. The higher the negative values for percent change in Partial Onset Seizure (POS) frequency, the higher the improvement from Baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Categorized Response From Baseline in Seizure Frequency for Partial Onset Seizure (Type I) Over the 16-week Treatment Period
secondary_outcome.description: Subjects were classified in 1 of the following categories based on their percent reduction from Baseline to Treatment Period in Partial Onset Seizure (POS) frequency per week: <-25 %, -25 % to <25 %, 25 % to <50 %, 50 % to <75 %, 75 % to <100 %, and 100 %. Subjects having zero for Baseline seizure frequency per week were classified in the <-25 % category.

secondary_outcome.measure: Seizure Freedom Rate (All Seizure Types) Over the 16-week Treatment Period
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (Week 0) to the end of Treatment Period (Week 16)
secondary_outcome.description: Subjects were considered seizure free if their seizure counts for every day over the Treatment Period (TP) was zero and if they did not discontinue before the end of the TP. Seizure freedom rate was calculated as: (total number of seizure - free subjects in treatment group during TP)/(total number of evaluable Intent-To-Treat (ITT) subjects in treatment group)

secondary_outcome.measure: Reduction of Type IC/Type I Seizure Frequency Ratio From Baseline to the 16-week Treatment Period
secondary_outcome.description: The type IC/Type I seizure frequency ratio is represented by the percentage of subjects having a reduction in the ratio of Type IC seizure frequency over Type IA, IB, and IC seizure frequency from Baseline to Treatment Period.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to First Type I Seizure During the 16-week Treatment Period
secondary_outcome.description: Time to first Type I seizure during the 16-week Treatment Period was measured in days.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Fifth Type I Seizure During the 16-week Treatment Period
secondary_outcome.description: Time to fifth Type I seizure during the 16-week Treatment Period was measured in days.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Tenth Type I Seizure During Treatment Period
secondary_outcome.description: Time to tenth Type I seizure during the 16-week Treatment Period was measured in days.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline to the 16-week Treatment Period in Total Patient Weighted Quality of Life in Epilepsy Inventory-Form 31 (QOLIE-31-P) Score
secondary_outcome.description: The Quality of Life in Epilepsy Inventory-Form 31 (QOLIE-31-P) is an adaptation of the original QOLIE-31 instrument that includes 30 items grouped into 7 multi-item subscales: Seizure Worry (5 items), Overall Quality of Life (2 items), Emotional Well-being (5 items), Energy/Fatigue (4 items), Cognitive Functioning (6 items), Medication Effects (3 items) and Daily Activities/Social Functioning (5 items), and a Health Status item. In addition to the 31 items of the QOLIE-31, the QOLIE-31-P contains 7 items asking the subjects to rate the degree of 'distress' related to the topic of each subscale (ie, distress items). The QOLIE-31-P also contains an item asking about the relative importance of each subscale topic (ie, prioritization item). The subscale scores, the total score and the Health Status item score were calculated according to the scoring algorithm defined by the author with scores ranging from 0 to 100 and higher scores indicating better function.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline to the 16-week Treatment Period in Seizure Worry Patient Weighted Quality of Life in Epilepsy Inventory-Form 31 (QOLIE-31-P) Score
secondary_outcome.description: The Quality of Life in Epilepsy Inventory-Form 31 (QOLIE-31-P) is an adaptation of the original QOLIE-31 instrument that includes 30 items grouped into 7 multi-item subscales: Seizure Worry (5 items), Overall Quality of Life (2 items), Emotional Well-being (5 items), Energy/Fatigue (4 items), Cognitive Functioning (6 items), Medication Effects (3 items) and Daily Activities/Social Functioning (5 items), and a Health Status item. In addition to the 31 items of the QOLIE-31, the QOLIE-31-P contains 7 items asking the subjects to rate the degree of 'distress' related to the topic of each subscale (ie, distress items). The QOLIE-31-P also contains an item asking about the relative importance of each subscale topic (ie, prioritization item). The subscale scores, the total score and the Health Status item score were calculated according to the scoring algorithm defined by the author with scores ranging from 0 to 100 and higher scores indicating better function.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline to the 16-week Treatment Period in Daily Activities / Social Functioning Patient Weighted Quality of Life in Epilepsy Inventory-Form 31 (QOLIE-31-P) Score
secondary_outcome.description: The Quality of Life in Epilepsy Inventory-Form 31 (QOLIE-31-P) is an adaptation of the original QOLIE-31 instrument that includes 30 items grouped into 7 multi-item subscales: Seizure Worry (5 items), Overall Quality of Life (2 items), Emotional Well-being (5 items), Energy/Fatigue (4 items), Cognitive Functioning (6 items), Medication Effects (3 items) and Daily Activities/Social Functioning (5 items), and a Health Status item. In addition to the 31 items of the QOLIE-31, the QOLIE-31-P contains 7 items asking the subjects to rate the degree of 'distress' related to the topic of each subscale (ie, distress items). The QOLIE-31-P also contains an item asking about the relative importance of each subscale topic (ie, prioritization item). The subscale scores, the total score and the Health Status item score were calculated according to the scoring algorithm defined by the author with scores ranging from 0 to 100 and higher scores indicating better function.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline to the 16-week Treatment Period in Hospital Anxiety Score
secondary_outcome.description: The Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) was used to evaluate Anxiety and Depression. The HADS was developed as a self-administered scale to assess the presence and severity of Anxiety and Depression. It consists of 14 items that are scored on a 4-point severity scale ranging from 0 to 3. A score per dimension was calculated with each score ranging from 0 to 21 (higher scores indicating greater problems). A negative value in change from Baseline indicates an improvement from Baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline to the 16-week Treatment Period in Hospital Depression Score
secondary_outcome.description: The Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) was used to evaluate Anxiety and Depression.The HADS was developed as a self-administered scale to assess the presence and severity of Anxiety and Depression. It consists of 14 items that are scored on a 4-point severity scale ranging from 0 to 3. A score per dimension was calculated with each score ranging from 0 to 21 (higher scores indicating greater problems). A negative value in change from Baseline indicates an improvement from Baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient's Global Evaluation Scale (P-GES) Evaluated at Last Visit or Early Discontinuation Visit
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to last visit or early discontinuation visit in the 16-week Treatment Period
secondary_outcome.description: The Patient's Global Evaluation Scale (P-GES) is a global assessment of the disease evolution which was performed using a seven-point scale (1= Marked worsening to 7= Marked improvement) with the start of the study medication as the reference time point. The subject completed it by answering to the following: 'Overall, has there been a change in your seizures since the start of the study medication?'

secondary_outcome.measure: Investigator's Global Evaluation Scale (I-GES) Evaluated at Last Visit or Early Discontinuation Visit
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline to Last Visit or Early Discontinuation Visit in the 16-week Treatment Period
secondary_outcome.description: The Investigator's Global Evaluation Scale (I-GES) is a global assessment of the disease evolution which was performed using a seven-point scale (1= Marked worsening to 7= Marked improvement) with the start of the study medication as the reference time point. The Investigator completed it by answering to the following: 'Assess the overall change in the severity of patient's illness, compared to start of study medication.'

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline to the 16-week Treatment Period in Energy/Fatigue Patient Weighted Quality of Life in Epilepsy Inventory-Form 31 (QOLIE-31-P) Score
secondary_outcome.description: The Quality of Life in Epilepsy Inventory-Form 31 (QOLIE-31-P) is an adaptation of the original QOLIE-31 instrument that includes 30 items grouped into 7 multi-item subscales: Seizure Worry (5 items), Overall Quality of Life (2 items), Emotional Well-being (5 items), Energy/Fatigue (4 items), Cognitive Functioning (6 items), Medication Effects (3 items) and Daily Activities/Social Functioning (5 items), and a Health Status item. The QOLIE-31-P also contains an item asking about the relative importance of each subscale topic (ie, prioritization item). The subscale scores, the total score and the Health Status item score were calculated according to the scoring algorithm defined by the author with scores ranging from 0 to 100 and higher scores indicating better function.

secondary_outcome.description: The Quality of Life in Epilepsy Inventory-Form 31 (QOLIE-31-P) is an adaptation of the original QOLIE-31 instrument that includes 30 items grouped into 7 multi-item subscales: Seizure Worry (5 items), Overall Quality of Life (2 items), Emotional Well-being (5 items), Energy/Fatigue (4 items), Cognitive Functioning (6 items), Medication Effects (3 items) and Daily Activities/Social Functioning (5 items), and a Health Status item. arm_group.description: Matching Placebo tablets administered twice a day
A flexible dose of Brivaracetam tablets, administered twice a day, starting with a dose of 20 mg/day and could increase to 50 mg/day, 100 mg/day or 150 mg/day

intervention.description: Daily oral dose of two equal intakes, morning and evening, of Placebo in a double-blinded way for the 16-week Treatment Period

Daily oral dose of two equal intakes, morning and evening, Brivaracetam 20 mg/day or Brivaracetam 50 mg/day or Brivaracetam 100 mg/day or Brivaracetam 150 mg/day, in a double-blinded way for the 16-week Treatment Period

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Subjects were aged from 16 to 70 years, inclusive. Subjects under 18 years of age were only included where legally permitted and ethically accepted
- Subjects had well-characterized localization-related Epilepsy or generalized Epilepsy according to the International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) classification
- For subjects suffering from localization-related Epilepsy: subjects had at least 2 Partial-Onset Seizures (POSs) whether or not secondarily generalized per month during the 3 months preceding Visit 1 according to the ILAE classification
- For subjects suffering from localization-related Epilepsy: subjects had at least 4 Partial-Onset Seizures (POSs) whether or not secondarily generalized during the 4-week Baseline Period according to the ILAE classification
- For subjects suffering from generalized Epilepsy: subjects had at least 2 Type II-seizure days per month during the 3 months preceding Visit 1 according to the ILAE classification
- For subjects suffering from generalized Epilepsy: subjects had at least 4 Type II-seizure days during the 4 week Baseline Period according to the ILAE classification
- Subjects were uncontrolled while treated by 1 to 3 permitted concomitant Antiepileptic Drugs (AEDs). Vagal nerve stimulation was allowed and was not counted as a concomitant AED
Exclusion Criteria:
- For subjects who suffered from localization-related Epilepsy: history or presence of Seizures occurring only in clusters (too frequently or indistinctly separated to be reliably counted) before Visit 2 or occurring only as Type IA non-motor
- Subjects with a history or presence of Status Epilepticus during the year preceding Visit 1 or during Baseline

results_reference.citation: Kwan P, Trinka E, Van Paesschen W, Rektor I, Johnson ME, Lu S. Adjunctive brivaracetam for uncontrolled focal and generalized epilepsies: results of a phase III, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, flexible-dose trial. Epilepsia. 2014 Jan;55(1):38-46. doi: 10.1111/epi.12391. Epub 2013 Oct 3.

Mukuria C, Young T, Keetharuth A, Borghs S, Brazier J. Sensitivity and responsiveness of the EQ-5D-3L in patients with uncontrolled focal seizures: an analysis of Phase III trials of adjunctive brivaracetam. Qual Life Res. 2017 Mar;26(3):749-759. doi: 10.1007/s11136-016-1483-3. Epub 2016 Dec 21.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: This multicenter study was conducted in 15 countries. It started in October 2007 and concluded in December 2008.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: The Participant Flow refers to the Randomized Set (RS).

outcome.title: Percentage of Subjects With at Least One Adverse Event During the 16-week Treatment Period
outcome.description: An Adverse Event (AE) is any untoward medical occurrence in a patient or clinical investigation subject administered a pharmaceutical product which does not necessarily have a causal relationship with this treatment. An AE can therefore be any unfavorable and unintended sign (including an abnormal laboratory finding), symptom, or disease temporally associated with the use of a medicinal (investigational) product, whether or not related to the medicinal (investigational) product.
outcome.time_frame: Week 2 to the end of the Treatment Period (Week 16)
outcome.population: The Safety Population was defined as all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication.

An AE can therefore be any unfavorable and unintended sign (including an abnormal laboratory finding), symptom, or disease temporally associated with the use of a medicinal (investigational) product, whether or not related to the medicinal (investigational) product.

Partial Onset Seizure (POS) frequency per week over the Treatment Period (TP) was calculated as: (Total Type I seizures over the TP)*7/(Total number of days with no missing seizure count in the TP)

outcome.population: Localization-related epilepsy Intent-To-Treat (ITT) Population (POS). The ITT Population was defined as all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication.

analysis.groups_desc: ANCOVA on log-transformed partial seizure frequency per week over the treatment period, with log-transformed baseline seizure frequency per week as covariate, and including terms for treatment and stratification factors.

Subjects with zero seizure frequency per week at Baseline were considered as non-responders.

group.description: A flexible dose of Brivaracetam tablets, administered twice a day, starting with a dose of 20 mg/day and could increase to 50 mg/day, 100 mg/day or 150 mg/day

measure.title: Seizure Freedom Rate (All Seizure Types) Over the 16-week Treatment Period
measure.description: Subjects were considered seizure free if their seizure counts for every day over the Treatment Period (TP) was zero and if they did not discontinue before the end of the TP. Seizure freedom rate was calculated as: (total number of seizure - free subjects in treatment group during TP)/(total number of evaluable Intent-To-Treat (ITT) subjects in treatment group)
measure.population: Localization-related epilepsy Intent-To-Treat (ITT) Population (POS). The ITT Population was defined as all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication.

outcome.title: Reduction of Type IC/Type I Seizure Frequency Ratio From Baseline to the 16-week Treatment Period
outcome.description: The type IC/Type I seizure frequency ratio is represented by the percentage of subjects having a reduction in the ratio of Type IC seizure frequency over Type IA, IB, and IC seizure frequency from Baseline to Treatment Period.
outcome.population: The Intention-to-treat (ITT) population was defined as all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication. Type IC Population consists of those subjects with at least one Type IC seizure during the Baseline period.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Matching Placebo tablets administered twice a day Placebo: Daily oral dose of two equal intakes, morning and evening, of Placebo in a double-blinded way for the 16-week Treatment Period

group.title: Brivaracetam
group.description: A flexible dose of Brivaracetam tablets, administered twice a day, starting with a dose of 20 mg/day and could increase to 50 mg/day, 100 mg/day or 150 mg/day Brivaracetam: Daily oral dose of two equal intakes, morning and evening, Brivaracetam 20 mg/day or Brivaracetam 50 mg/day or Brivaracetam 100 mg/day or Brivaracetam 150 mg/day, in a double-blinded way for the 16-week Treatment Period

measure.title: Reduction of Type IC/Type I Seizure Frequency Ratio From Baseline to the 16-week Treatment Period
measure.description: The type IC/Type I seizure frequency ratio is represented by the percentage of subjects having a reduction in the ratio of Type IC seizure frequency over Type IA, IB, and IC seizure frequency from Baseline to Treatment Period.
measure.population: The Intention-to-treat (ITT) population was defined as all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication. Type IC Population consists of those subjects with at least one Type IC seizure during the Baseline period.

outcome.title: Time to First Type I Seizure During the 16-week Treatment Period
outcome.description: Time to first Type I seizure during the 16-week Treatment Period was measured in days.
outcome.population: Localization-related epilepsy Intent-To-Treat (ITT) Population (POS). The ITT Population was defined as all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication.

group.description: Matching Placebo tablets administered twice a day

measure.title: Time to First Type I Seizure During the 16-week Treatment Period

outcome.population: Localization-related epilepsy Intent-To-Treat (ITT) Population (POS). The ITT Population was defined as all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication.

outcome.title: Time to Tenth Type I Seizure During Treatment Period
outcome.description: Time to tenth Type I seizure during the 16-week Treatment Period was measured in days.
outcome.population: Localization-related epilepsy Intent-To-Treat (ITT) Population (POS). The ITT Population was defined as all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Matching Placebo tablets administered twice a day

group.title: Brivaracetam
group.description: A flexible dose of Brivaracetam tablets, administered twice a day, starting with a dose of 20 mg/day and could increase to 50 mg/day, 100 mg/day or 150 mg/day

measure.title: Time to Tenth Type I Seizure During Treatment Period
measure.description: Time to tenth Type I seizure during the 16-week Treatment Period was measured in days.
measure.population: Localization-related epilepsy Intent-To-Treat (ITT) Population (POS). The ITT Population was defined as all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline to the 16-week Treatment Period in Total Patient Weighted Quality of Life in Epilepsy Inventory-Form 31 (QOLIE-31-P) Score
outcome.description: The Quality of Life in Epilepsy Inventory-Form 31 (QOLIE-31-P) is an adaptation of the original QOLIE-31 instrument that includes 30 items grouped into 7 multi-item subscales: Seizure Worry (5 items), Overall Quality of Life (2 items), Emotional Well-being (5 items), Energy/Fatigue (4 items), Cognitive Functioning (6 items), Medication Effects (3 items) and Daily Activities/Social Functioning (5 items), and a Health Status item. In addition to the 31 items of the QOLIE-31, the QOLIE-31-P contains 7 items asking the subjects to rate the degree of 'distress' related to the topic of each subscale (ie, distress items). The QOLIE-31-P also contains an item asking about the relative importance of each subscale topic (ie, prioritization item). The subscale scores, the total score and the Health Status item score were calculated according to the scoring algorithm defined by the author with scores ranging from 0 to 100 and higher scores indicating better function.
outcome.population: Localization-related epilepsy Intent-To-Treat (ITT) Population (POS). The ITT Population was defined as all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication. Only subjects who are not mentally impaired were to complete the QOLIE-31-P. Only subjects having values at baseline and at the considered visit are included.

Only subjects who are not mentally impaired were to complete the QOLIE-31-P. Only subjects having values at baseline and at the considered visit are included.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline to the 16-week Treatment Period in Hospital Anxiety Score
outcome.description: The Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) was used to evaluate Anxiety and Depression. The HADS was developed as a self-administered scale to assess the presence and severity of Anxiety and Depression. It consists of 14 items that are scored on a 4-point severity scale ranging from 0 to 3. A score per dimension was calculated with each score ranging from 0 to 21 (higher scores indicating greater problems). A negative value in change from Baseline indicates an improvement from Baseline.
outcome.population: Localization-related epilepsy Intent-To-Treat (ITT) Population (POS). The ITT Population was defined as all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication. Only subjects who are not mentally impaired were to complete the HADS. Only subjects having values at baseline ans at the considered visit are included.

outcome.title: Patient's Global Evaluation Scale (P-GES) Evaluated at Last Visit or Early Discontinuation Visit
outcome.description: The Patient's Global Evaluation Scale (P-GES) is a global assessment of the disease evolution which was performed using a seven-point scale (1= Marked worsening to 7= Marked improvement) with the start of the study medication as the reference time point. The subject completed it by answering to the following: 'Overall, has there been a change in your seizures since the start of the study medication?'
outcome.time_frame: Baseline to last visit or early discontinuation visit in the 16-week Treatment Period
outcome.population: Localization-related epilepsy Intent-To-Treat (ITT) Population (POS). The ITT Population was defined as all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication. Evaluable subjects are subjects who completed the GES at last treatment period visit.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Matching Placebo tablets administered twice a day

group.title: Brivaracetam

measure.title: Patient's Global Evaluation Scale (P-GES) Evaluated at Last Visit or Early Discontinuation Visit
measure.description: The Patient's Global Evaluation Scale (P-GES) is a global assessment of the disease evolution which was performed using a seven-point scale (1= Marked worsening to 7= Marked improvement) with the start of the study medication as the reference time point. measure.population: Localization-related epilepsy Intent-To-Treat (ITT) Population (POS). The ITT Population was defined as all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication. Evaluable subjects are subjects who completed the GES at last treatment period visit.

outcome.title: Investigator's Global Evaluation Scale (I-GES) Evaluated at Last Visit or Early Discontinuation Visit
outcome.description: The Investigator's Global Evaluation Scale (I-GES) is a global assessment of the disease evolution which was performed using a seven-point scale (1= Marked worsening to 7= Marked improvement) with the start of the study medication as the reference time point. The Investigator completed it by answering to the following: 'Assess the overall change in the severity of patient's illness, compared to start of study medication.'
outcome.time_frame: Baseline to Last Visit or Early Discontinuation Visit in the 16-week Treatment Period
outcome.population: Localization-related epilepsy Intent-To-Treat (ITT) Population (POS). The ITT Population was defined as all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication. Evaluable subjects are subjects for whom the GES was completed by the investigator at last treatment period visit.

In addition to the 31 items of the QOLIE-31, the QOLIE-31-P contains 7 items asking the subjects to rate the degree of 'distress' related to the topic of each subscale (ie, distress items). The QOLIE-31-P also contains an item asking about the relative importance of each subscale topic (ie, prioritization item). The subscale scores, the total score and the Health Status item score were calculated according to the scoring algorithm defined by the author with scores ranging from 0 to 100 and higher scores indicating better function.
measure.population: Localization-related epilepsy Intent-To-Treat (ITT) Population (POS). The ITT Population was defined as all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication. Only subjects who are not mentally impaired were to complete the QOLIE-31-P. Only subjects having values at baseline and at the considered visit are included.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline to the 16-week Treatment Period in Overall Patient Weighted Quality of Life in Epilepsy Inventory-Form 31 (QOLIE-31-P) Score
outcome.description: The Quality of Life in Epilepsy Inventory-Form 31 (QOLIE-31-P) is an adaptation of the original QOLIE-31 instrument that includes 30 items grouped into 7 multi-item subscales: Seizure Worry (5 items), Overall Quality of Life (2 items), Emotional Well-being (5 items), Energy/Fatigue (4 items), Cognitive Functioning (6 items), Medication Effects (3 items) and Daily Activities/Social Functioning (5 items), and a Health Status item. In addition to the 31 items of the QOLIE-31, the QOLIE-31-P contains 7 items asking the subjects to rate the degree of 'distress' related to the topic of each subscale (ie, distress items). The QOLIE-31-P also contains an item asking about the relative importance of each subscale topic (ie, prioritization item). The subscale scores, the total score and the Health Status item score were calculated according to the scoring algorithm defined by the author with scores ranging from 0 to 100 and higher scores indicating better function.
outcome.population: Localization-related epilepsy Intent-To-Treat (ITT) Population (POS). The ITT Population was defined as all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication. Only subjects who are not mentally impaired were to complete the QOLIE-31-P. Only subjects having values at baseline and at the considered visit are included.

group.description: Matching Placebo tablets administered twice a day

group.title: Brivaracetam
group.description: A flexible dose of Brivaracetam tablets, administered twice a day, starting with a dose of 20 mg/day and could increase to 50 mg/day, 100 mg/day or 150 mg/day

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse Events (AEs) were collected up to 24 weeks from Visit 1 (Week -4) to the Safety Visit (Week 20).
reported_events.desc: Adverse Events (AEs) refer to the Safety Population, including all randomized subjects who received at least 1 dose of study medication.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Matching Placebo tablets administered twice a day

group.title: Brivaracetam
group.description: A flexible dose of Brivaracetam tablets, administered twice a day, starting with a dose of 20 mg/day and could increase to 50 mg/day, 100 mg/day or 150 mg/day

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is more than 60 days but less than or equal to 180 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.
